clinical_study.brief_title: Weight Variation During Chemotherapy in Breast Cancer Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Weight Variation and Mechanisms Involved, During Chemotherapy in Breast Cancer Patients

brief_summary.textblock:
Weight variation has been reported as a side effect of chemotherapy treatment in early breast cancer patients. To date, there is growing evidence for an increased risk of relapse and death in these patients who gain or lose weight. However, causes of weight variation during chemotherapy and mechanisms involved in the poor prognosis have been little studied.
Thus, the investigators are conducting a prospective study to characterize weight variation in terms of body composition and to identify the mechanisms involved.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in body composition
primary_outcome.time_frame: within 2 weeks before chemotherapy; 1month after the last chemotherapy; and 6 months later.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in energy balance
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 2 weeks before chemotherapy; 1month after the last chemotherapy; and 6 months later.
secondary_outcome.description: resting energy expenditure, physical activity, food records.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in muscle strength
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 2 weeks before chemotherapy; 1month after the last chemotherapy; and 6 months later.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in biological factors (hormonal, inflammatory, lipid, growth factors)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 2 weeks before chemotherapy; 1month after the last chemotherapy; and 6 months later.

intervention.description: blood test (hormonal, inflammatory, lipid and growth factors); body composition measurements; energy balance evaluation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- menopausal women
- breast cancer
- patients requiring chemotherapy treatment
- WHO performance status 0-2
Exclusion Criteria:
- diabetics
- patients with metastases
- other cancer
